question: Many working people get little or no exercise either during the working day or in their free, and have health problems as a result. Why do many working people not get enough exercise? What can be done about this problem?
text: In recent years, the engagement with physical exercise has started decreasing in an early as well as a full professionals’ lives. Due to the lack of inspiration for exercise, health problems such as obesity, blood pressure and so on begin to rise in working class. For a scheduled rule of working so many hours, each employee loses interest on continuing paid keep-fit studio nevertheless few awareness campaigns towards the consequences of health diseases could change the present scenario.

It is generally believed by the most of workers that people find it a bit exhausting to jog or walk for thirty minutes before or after a long working day. In addition, not being consistent from the very beginning for to keep the health fit. For an example, a growing number of Indian graduates stops playing soccer or cricket after getting into a job. Consequently, mental tiredness and aversion to physical work intimidate all kinds of professional to avoid keep-fit studios.

The taboo can easily be broken if there are a myriad amount of promotion of the health effects. Furthermore, widely spread advertisement campaigns can convey the core message so that implications of getting a balanced life can be understood. As an example, 30% people started using cycles as their office transportation after a joint promotion from an advertising agency and US government in 2015. Hence, the conversion rate of getting exercises from awareness programs will be seemed higher.

Will the exercise speak louder than the physical problems? To conclude with, there are no alternatives than exercises to win a good health. In spite of tight office hours health campaigns may have the best chance to allure the working citizens to sign up for the exercises.

error_list.error: conduit consisting of a long hollow object (usually cylindrical) used to hold and conduct objects or liquids or gases
